Representation.Label: Enumerated value concepts for application building
Representation.Detail: This document is generated by an xslt script from the enumerations present in the following schema: "Unified Biosciences Information Framework (UBIF) 1.1". Enumerations are converted to SDD descriptive concepts (enumerated values are represented by concept states). The html report generated for these values / concept states is intended for documentation and to improve discussion and correction of errors (please comment on http://wiki.tdwg.org/twiki/bin/view/UBIF/EnumeratedValues). The xml representation follows the general conventions of UBIF documents and may be easier to import or integrate into user interfaces than the schema itself. This is especially true for SDD documents, where a large part of the terminology is provided in the form of data documents by the experts of a given knowledge domain. This document can be used side-by-side as schema-defined terminology with user-defined terminology.

Representation.Label: RevisionStatus
Representation.Detail: Controlled vocabulary expressing the revision status as assessed by creators or editors or objects. It may apply to an entire data set as well as to individual objects (a specimen, a taxon name, a description, etc.). Exact semantics are defined only for the first and the last two categories. The semantics of the intermediate levels (1 to 5) may be chosen freely by the user (and associated with the actual, project dependend workflow, e.g. 'draft', 'review', 'approved', 'stable'). The added semantics should, however, conserve the order of revision status values. If, for example, three revision steps are planned (2 intermediate, reaching FullyRevised on third), it is recommended to use RevisionLevel2, RevisionLevel4, FullyRevised.

Representation.Label: Unrevised
Representation.Detail: The data have been input, but no separate revision was performed.

Representation.Label: Revision level 1 of 5
Representation.Detail: For example, in a collection less than ca. 20 % of the data are revised, or on a single object only a plausibility check has been performed.

Representation.Label: Revision level 2 of 5
Representation.Detail: For example, in a collection ca. 41-60 % of the data are revised, or on a single object the data are compared carefully with the source.

Representation.Label: Revision level 3 of 5
Representation.Detail: For example, ca. 41-60 % of the data are revised.

Representation.Label: Revision level 4 of 5
Representation.Detail: For example, ca. 61-80 % of the data are revised.

Representation.Label: Revision level 5 of 5
Representation.Detail: For example, more than 80% revised (but not yet completed).

Representation.Label: Revision completed
Representation.Detail: The data are completely revised given the available time and the goals set for the project. This does not necessarily imply that the data are complete and perfectly revised in a scientific sense.

Representation.Label: Deprecated
Representation.Detail: An object concept should no longer be used, but is not deleted because external data depend on it. This revision status applies, e.g. to definitions in shared descriptive terminologies.

Representation.Label: ExpertiseLevel
Representation.Detail: Controlled vocabulary expressing the expertise exprected or required from human consumers of data or services. Values are restricted to integer values from 0 to 5. 0 is defined as unspecified level, and 1 to 5 indicates expertise from schoolchildren to taxonomic expert. See the description of the values for recommendations for interpreting and choosing the expert level.

Representation.Label: 0 = Unspecified expertise level
Representation.Detail: Use this if the expertise level of can not be assessed (e. g. when exporting data) or is considered irrelevant.

Representation.Label: 3 = High school (year 11 above) and general public
Representation.Detail: When addressing this level specialized terminology or jargon should be avoided.

Representation.Label: 4 = University students or (partly) trained staff
Representation.Detail: This level uses specialized terminology, but avoids or explains problematic terms.

Representation.Label: 5 = Experts
Representation.Detail: This level uses the full range of terminology

Representation.Label: ResourceType
Representation.Detail: This enumeration is identical with the DCMI Type Vocabulary (http: //dublincore.org/documents/dcmi-terms/, as of 6/2004), except that an additional type "Other" has been added. Its purpose is to provide a framework of broad media or resource type terms, without the technical detail provided by the large number of MIME types. The annotations are largely based on those from the DublinCore metadata initiative vocabulary.

Representation.Label: Collection
Representation.Detail: A collection is an aggregation of items. The term collection means that the resource is described as a group; its parts may be separately described and navigated.

Representation.Label: Dataset
Representation.Detail: A dataset is information encoded in a defined structure (for example, lists, tables, and databases), intended to be useful for direct machine processing.

Representation.Label: Event
Representation.Detail: An event is a non-persistent, time-based occurrence. Metadata for an event provides descriptive information that is the basis for discovery of the purpose, location, duration, responsible agents, and links to related events and resources. The resource of type event may not be retrievable if the described instantiation has expired or is yet to occur. Examples - exhibition, web-cast, conference, workshop, open-day, performance, battle, trial, wedding, tea-party, conflagration.

Representation.Label: Image
Representation.Detail: An image is a primarily symbolic visual representation other than text. For example - images and photographs of physical objects, paintings, prints, drawings, other images and graphics, animations and moving pictures, film, diagrams, maps, musical notation. Note that image may include both electronic and physical representations.

Representation.Label: Interactive Resource
Representation.Detail: An interactive resource is a resource which requires interaction from the user to be understood, executed, or experienced. For example - forms on web pages, applets, multimedia learning objects, chat services, virtual reality.

Representation.Label: Moving Image (Video)
Representation.Detail: A series of visual representations that, when shown in succession, impart an impression of motion. Examples of moving images are: animations, movies, television programs, videos, zoetropes, or visual output from a simulation. Comment: Instances of the type "Moving Image" must also be describable as instances of the broader type "Image".

Representation.Label: Physical Object
Representation.Detail: An inanimate, three-dimensional object or substance. For example -- a computer, the great pyramid, a sculpture. Note that digital representations of, or surrogates for, these things should use Image, Text or one of the other types.

Representation.Label: Service
Representation.Detail: A service is a system that provides one or more functions of value to the end-user. Examples include: a photocopying service, a banking service, an authentication service, interlibrary loans, a Z39.50 or Web server.

Representation.Label: Software
Representation.Detail: Software is a computer program in source or compiled form which may be available for installation non-transiently on another machine. For software which exists only to create an interactive environment, use interactive instead.

Representation.Label: Sound
Representation.Detail: A sound is a resource whose content is primarily intended to be rendered as audio. For example - a music playback file format, an audio compact disc, and recorded speech or sounds.

Representation.Label: Still Image
Representation.Detail: A static visual representation. Examples of still images are: paintings, drawings, graphic designs, plans and maps. Comment: Recommended best practice is to assign the type "Text" to images of textual materials. Instances of the type "Still Image" must also be describable as instances of the broader type "Image".

Representation.Label: Text
Representation.Detail: A text is a resource whose content is primarily words for reading. For example - books, letters, dissertations, poems, newspapers, articles, archives of mailing lists. Note that facsimiles or images of texts are still of the genre text. Text may contain embedded still image illustrations, e. g., formatted html pages.

Representation.Label: Other
Representation.Detail: Use this category if the resource does not seem to fit into any of the categories provided above.

Representation.Label: TelephoneDevice
Representation.Detail: Kind of phone number: voice, fax, mobile, pager, modem. These enumerated values are identical with vCard 3.0 flags (several of which can be added to a single phone number; to represent this in the UBIF interface duplicate the phone number itself!)

Representation.Label: Rating1to5
Representation.Detail: Enumeration restricted to integer values from 1 to 5, indicating an arbitrary rating (meaning, e. g., 1 = disagree strongly, 2 = rather disagree, 3 = neutral or undecided, 4 = rather agree, 5 = agree strongly). This enumeration is of limited usefulness and could be replaced by an restriction on integer, but using the enumeration the semantics of agreement/disagreement or positive/negative rating can be communicated in a culture-neutral way (in German 1 is generally considered best and 5 worst, in English 1 worst, 5 best...).
Representation.Label: Rating1to5
Representation.Detail: Aufzählung von ganzzahligen Werten zwischen 0 u. 5 für beliebige Bewertungsskalen. Beispiel für Interpretation der 5 Werte: 1 = ablehnend, 2 = eher ablehnend, 3 =neutral oder unentschieden, 4 = eher zustimmend, 5 = zustimmend)

Representation.Label: Rating "0"
Representation.Detail: Undecided (not yet rated).

Representation.Label: Rating "1"
Representation.Detail: For example, "disagree strongly", or "very poor".

Representation.Label: Rating "2"
Representation.Detail: For example, "rather disagree", or "poor".

Representation.Label: Rating "3"
Representation.Detail: For example, "neutral", "average", "undecided".

Representation.Label: Rating "4"
Representation.Detail: For example, "rather agree", or "good".

Representation.Label: Rating "5"
Representation.Detail: For example, "agree strongly", or "very good".

Representation.Label: TextDirectionality
Representation.Detail: Values are ltr (left to right), rtl (right to left). Compare CSS2 and the XHTML 2.0 bi-directional text module. Note: A future UBIF version may also include lro/rlo = left-right-overide/right-left-overide, if this is found to be necessary.

Representation.Label: StringFormattingType
Representation.Detail: Controlled vocabulary expressing whether and which kind of inline formatting may be contained in a text literal (plain, inline-entity-encoded, html-level-entity-encoded). In the absence of an attribute providing further specification, most UBIF text elements may contain "inline" entity-escaped formatting! (Other standards: ~=atom:title/@type)

Representation.Label: plain, unformatted text
plain
Representation.Detail: The element contains plain text with no entity escaped html. The entire text will contain the same format, i.e. it can contain not superscript, subscript or italicized parts. Example: "Mg2Cl > 10mMol" (xml-entities like greater-than are still entity escaped!). Other standards: atom:title/@type=text.

Representation.Label: formatted text using selected html inline elements
inline
Representation.Detail: The element contains html formatting from an enumerated list of html inline formatting commands: strong, em, b, i, sub, sup, br. Other html commands (including inline formatting like a and img) are not recognized. Example: "Mg<sub>2</sub>Cl > 10mMol". Note: the constrained list of formats enables processors with limited implementation cost to render the formatting in other formats than the html-family.

Representation.Label: formatted text using html elements
html
Representation.Detail: The element contains html formatting commands for an enumerated list of html inline formatting commands: strong, em, b, i, sub, sup, br. Other html commands (including inline formatting like a and img) are not recognized. Example: "Mg<sub>2</sub>Cl > 10mMol". Other standards: atom:title/@type=html. Note: atom also provides a value "xhtml", in which case the element content is directly full xhtml (i.e. contains mixed content). Such mixed content formatting was provided in early proposals of UBIF, but was rejected because it created significantly increased implementation cost in applications, including xslt in general and xml-database conversions. See EncodedFormattingProposal.zip for further information.

Representation.Label: MeasurementUnitPrefix
Representation.Detail: Multiplication factor prefixes used in the scientific SI system (T, G, M, k, h, c, m, µ, n, p, f, a).

Representation.Label: tera
T
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of 12. Example: TW, terawatt.
Representation.Label: Tera
T
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch 12.

Representation.Label: giga
G
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of 9. Example: GV, gigavolt.
Representation.Label: Giga
G
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch 9.

Representation.Label: mega
M
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of 6. Example: MW, megawatt.
Representation.Label: Mega
M
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch 6.

Representation.Label: kilo
k
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 1000. Example: kg, kilogram.
Representation.Label: Kilo
k
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 1000.

Representation.Label: hecto
h
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 100. Example: hPa, hectopascal.
Representation.Label: Hekto
h
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 100.

Representation.Label: deca
da
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10. Example: daL, decaliter.
Representation.Label: Deka
da
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10.

Representation.Label: (none)
Representation.Detail: No prefix, denoting factor or 1. Example: g, gram.
Representation.Label: (keine)
Representation.Detail: Kein Prefix, entspricht einem Faktor von 1.

Representation.Label: deci
d
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting a factor of 0.1. Example: dm, decimeter.
Representation.Label: Dezi
d
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 0.1.

Representation.Label: centi
c
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting a factor of 0.01. Example: cm, centimeter.
Representation.Label: Centi
c
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 0.01.

Representation.Label: milli
m
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of -3. Example: mg, milligram.
Representation.Label: Milli
m
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch -3.

Representation.Label: micro
µ
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of -6. Example: µg, microgram.
Representation.Label: Mikro
µ
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch -6.

Representation.Label: nano
n
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of -9. Example: ng, nanogram.
Representation.Label: Nano
n
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch -9.

Representation.Label: pico
p
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of -12. Example: pmol, picomol.
Representation.Label: Piko
p
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch -12.

Representation.Label: femto
f
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of -15. Example: fm, femtometer.
Representation.Label: Femto
f
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch -15.

Representation.Label: atto
a
Representation.Detail: Prefix of measurement units, denoting 10 to the power of -18. Example: attotesla.
Representation.Label: Atto
a
Representation.Detail: Prefix wissenschaftlicher Maßeinheiten, entspricht einem Faktor von 10 hoch -18.

Representation.Label: StatisticalMeasurementScale
Representation.Detail: In statistical analysis it is often vital to know some basic properties of the values that are being analyzed. Some of these properties can be summarized in the form of a measurement scale. Higher scales can always be analyzed under the assumptions of a lower scale (ordinal data can be analyzed as nominal, ratio as interval).
Representation.Label: StatisticalMeasurementScale
Representation.Detail: In principal it would be desirable to define values in small enumerations, and then the supersets as: xs:union memberTypes="QuantitativeMeasurementScaleEnum CategoricalMeasurementScaleEnum"/. Compare other comments for restriction-problems Xerces has with this.

Representation.Label: nominal
Representation.Detail: unordered categorical states (DELTA character type 'UM')

Representation.Label: ordinal
Representation.Detail: ordered categorical states (DELTA character type 'OM'). Unless a separate tree defines more specific ordering, the order is assumed to be linear in the sequence in which the categories are enumerated in their definition.

Representation.Label: interval
Representation.Detail: real numeric (= floating point) values, where 0 is an arbitrarily defined point. As a consequence, ratios are undefined and only the intervals between values can be analyzed. Example: Temperature in °C or °F.

Representation.Label: ratio
Representation.Detail: real numeric (= floating point) values (DELTA: type 'RN'), where 0 is an objective point and ratios can thus be analyzed. Example: length measurements. Most measures belong into this category and it is acceptable to assume the 'ratio' scale when importing DELTA legacy data.

Representation.Label: QuantitativeMeasurementScale
Representation.Detail: Those values from StatisticalMeasurementScaleEnum addressing numerical data ('ratio' and 'interval'). Note: Occasionally "integer" or "cardinal" (versus real numbers) are also considered part of the measurement scale. This should be avoided because: a) All combinations of interval/ratio and discrete/continous are possible. b) The important distinction is whether a measurement is based on a continuous or discrete scale. Although in most cases this is equivalent with integer versus real numbers, it is not necessarily so. An ANOVA will report false significance not only when values come from "1, 2, 3 and 4", but also when they come from "1.2, 2.4, 3.6 and 4.8".

Representation.Label: Interval
Representation.Detail: (see value "Interval" defined elsewhere)

Representation.Label: Ratio
Representation.Detail: (see value "Ratio" defined elsewhere)

Representation.Label: CategoricalMeasurementScale
Representation.Detail: Those values from StatisticalMeasurementScaleEnum addressing categorical data ('nominal' and 'ordinal').

Representation.Label: Nominal
Representation.Detail: (see value "Nominal" defined elsewhere)

Representation.Label: Ordinal
Representation.Detail: (see value "Ordinal" defined elsewhere)

Representation.Label: DataStatus
Representation.Detail: Status values (examples: "unknown", "not applicable") identify standardized reasons why data are missing. Alternative names are 'missing data indicators', 'special states', 'Null-values'. The annotation labels of the values can be freely changed as long as the semantics are preserved.

Representation.Label: To be checked
Representation.Detail: Explicit indicator to revisit data later. This may occur when data are missing (known to exist, but not at hand for entering) or together with data (check entered data against additional information source).

Representation.Label: Not to be recorded (a decision was made not enter data)
ø
Representation.Detail: (No DELTA equivalent exists. Implemented in Lucid 3 as "scope out".)

Representation.Label: Not applicable (data are assumed to be impossible to exist)
Representation.Detail: The character has been studied, but is not applicable. Example are situations where the character cannot possibly exists (e. g. leaf-tip in a leaf-less plant) or where the method is unable to measure the current situation (e. g. a growth rate if available space is used before the time defined in the method). In the first situation it may be desirable to create a character dependency definition, making the scoring of individual characters no longer necessary. (Note: the DELTA equivalent is the '-'-state.)

Representation.Label: Data unavailable (could not be obtained despite that an effort was made)
Representation.Detail: The character has been studied and information has been searched, but not found. Use this to indicate that coding attempts should stop, perhaps until the next major revision. If data are currently unavailable, but attempts should continue, use '# = to be checked' instead. Compare also "not interpretable" if information found that is not interpretable. (Note: the DELTA equivalent is normally the 'U', but 'U' may also be used differently.)

Representation.Label: Not interpretable (data known to exist, but interpretation considered too uncertain).
Representation.Detail: The character has been studied and information has been found, but is impossible to score because the information is not interpretable under the current terminology. Using this status value warns collaborators that some information has already been studied (a specific annotation text accompanying the status value is recommend). Examples for using 'not interpretable': terms used in the source are undefined and cannot be guessed, the information in the source is contradictory, the color of a specimen is deteriorated so much that the original color can no longer be guessed. Note that in some cases an alternative to not coding at all may be to use certainty modifiers like 'perhaps' to make a tentative statement. (Note: no DELTA equivalent exists.)

Representation.Label: Data withheld (exist in source of current document, but private or confidential).
Representation.Detail: (Note: no DELTA equivalent exists.)

Representation.Label: UnivarAnyStatMeasure
Representation.Detail: Enumerated list of univariate statistical methods. The list is intended to be more complete than normally necessary at least in biological morphometrics. If you still miss some measures, please request additions in a future version of this schema. Note: No satisfying external ontology for statistical methods could be found; the statistics section of MathML 2.0 (statistics.xsd) seems rather incomplete!

Representation.Label: Lower range limit (human estimate)
Representation.Detail: Free estimate made by human observer for the lower range limit (no statistical sampling and calculation was used). This method is appropriate when it is known that the values are derived from experience with the described objects (perhaps from memory) or from scanning a sample of objects and measuring those objects considered 'typical'. This method is not appropriate for single measurements or for calculations based on statistical methods (which provide exact 'statistical estimates'). Compare also the 'UnknownMethod'-methods that are provided for legacy data.
Representation.Label: Untere Grenze (Schätzwert, ohne Berechnung)
Representation.Detail: Freie Schätzung ohne Verwendung statistischer Probenahme und Berechnung.

ues:Specification.debuglabel: ### This and the following methods cover non-statistical methods that are frequently encountered in taxonomic publications. They are specified with MethodClass = ObserverEstimate or UnknownMethod. Most other methods are implicitly derived from a generalized hypothetical 'StatisticalEstimate' method.

Representation.Label: Upper range limit (human estimate)
Representation.Detail: Free estimate made by human observer for the upper range limit (no statistical sampling and calculation was used). This method is appropriate when it is known that the values are derived from experience with the described objects (perhaps from memory) or from scanning a sample of objects and measuring those objects considered 'typical'. This method is not appropriate for single measurements or for calculations based on statistical methods (which provide exact 'statistical estimates'). Compare also the 'UnknownMethod'-methods that are provided for legacy data.
Representation.Label: Obere Grenze (Schätzwert, ohne Berechnung)
Representation.Detail: Freie Schätzung ohne Verwendung statistischer Probenahme und Berechnung.

Representation.Label: Central or typical value (human estimate)
centr.
Representation.Detail: Free estimate made by human observer for a single central or typical value (no statistical sampling and calculation was used). This method is appropriate when it is known that the values are derived from experience with the described objects (perhaps from memory) or from scanning a sample of objects and measuring those objects considered 'typical'. It is not appropriate for single measurements nor for calculations based on statistical methods (which provide exact 'statistical estimates'). Compare also the 'UnknownMethod'-methods that are provided for legacy data.
Representation.Label: Mittlerer oder typischer Wert (Schätzwert, ohne Berechnung)
centr.
Representation.Detail: Freie Schätzung ohne Verwendung statistischer Probenahme und Berechnung.

Representation.Label: Lower range limit (legacy data, stat. meth. unknown)
Representation.Detail: Lower range limit obtained by an unknown method (e. g. human observer estimate or some kind of statistical estimate). The range may, e. g., be mean plus/minus standard deviation, or a range estimate. 'Unknown' is important for legacy data where the statistical measure used is not known. If it is known that a measure is a human observer estimate rather than a defined value, the 'ObserverEstimate' methods should be used instead.

Representation.Label: Upper range limit (legacy data, stat. meth. unknown)
Representation.Detail: Upper range limit obtained by an unknown method (e. g. human observer estimate or some kind of statistical estimate). The range may, e. g., be mean plus/minus standard deviation, or a range estimate. 'Unknown' is important for legacy data where the statistical measure used is not known. If it is known that a measure is a human observer estimate rather than a defined value, the 'ObserverEstimate' methods should be used instead.

Representation.Label: Central or typical value (legacy data, stat. meth. unknown)
centr.(?)
Representation.Detail: Central or typical value obtained by an unknown method (e. g. human observer estimate or some kind of statistical estimate). The central value may, e. g., be a single measurement, median, or arithmetic mean. 'Unknown' is important for legacy data where the statistical measure used is not known. If it is known that a measure is a human observer estimate rather than a defined value, the 'ObserverEstimate' methods should be used instead.
Representation.Label: Mittlerer/typischer Wert (genaue Definition unbekannt)
Mittl.(?)
Minimum value
Min
Representation.Detail: Absolute smallest value
Representation.Label: Minimum
Min
Representation.Detail: Der kleinste beobachtete Wert

ues:Specification.debuglabel: ### Minimum/maximum are generally semantically identical, regardless whether human observer estimates or statistical estimates have been used. They are therefore only provided as statistical estimates, and it is suggested that human estimates of minimum or maximum are treated as statistical estimates with unknown sample size.

Representation.Label: Maximum value
Max
Representation.Detail: Absolute largest value
Representation.Label: Maximum
Max
Representation.Detail: Der größte beobachtete Wert

Representation.Label: Mean (= average)
µ
Representation.Detail: This is the normal, arithmetic mean.
Representation.Label: Mittelwert
µ
Representation.Detail: Dies ist der normale, arithmetische Mittelwert.

ues:Specification.debuglabel: ### This and the following are central measures:

Representation.Label: Harmonic mean
hµ
Representation.Detail: The harmonic mean (reciprocal of the arithmetic mean of reciprocals) is rarely used. Recommendation: if nothing specific is said about a "mean", it can safely be assumed to be an arithmetic mean.
Representation.Label: Harmonischer Mittelwert
hµ
Representation.Detail: Der harmonische Mittelwert (Inverses des Mittelwert der inverses Werte) wird nur selten verwendet. Empfehlung: wenn keine genauere Angabe zu einem Mittelwert gemacht wird kann man davon ausgehen, dass es sich um den arithmetischen Mittelwert handelt.

Representation.Label: Geometric mean
gµ
Representation.Detail: The geometric mean (antilog of mean of logarithms) is relatively rarely used. Recommendation: if nothing specific is said about a "mean", it can safely be assumed to be an arithmetic mean.
Representation.Label: Geometrischer Mittelwert
gµ
Representation.Detail: Der geometrische Mittelwert (Umkehrlogarithmus des Mittelwertes der logarithmierten Werte) wird nur sehr selten verwendet. Empfehlung: Wenn keine genauere Angabe zu einem Mittelwert gemacht wird kann man davon ausgehen, dass es sich um den arithmetischen Mittelwert handelt.

Representation.Label: Mode
mode
Representation.Detail: The value or value class with the highest frequency (most frequently occurring). Applicable only to unimodal distributions.
Representation.Label: Modus
mod.
Median
med.
Representation.Detail: The median is the 50 % percentile, i.e. 50% of the sampled values are smaller and the rest is larger than this value.
Representation.Label: Median (Zentralwert)
med.
Representation.Detail: Der Median ist das 50% Quantil, d.h. 50% der Werte sind kleiner, und ebenso viele größer als dieser Wert.

ues:Specification.debuglabel: Note that the median is identical to a percentile with measure parameter 50%. Since percentiles have been split into upper and lower range limits, this is not possible, however.

Representation.Label: Interquartile mean (= average)
IQM
Representation.Detail: A truncated arithmetic mean, calculated only from those values that lie between 25 and 75% of sample values. This reduces the dependency of the mean on outliers and measurement errors.
Representation.Label: Interquartilsmittelwert
IQM
Representation.Detail: Der arithmentische Mittelwert berechnet auf der Basis der in das symmetrische Intervall um den Median (= 50% der Beobachtungen) fallenden Werten.

Representation.Label: Variance (sample, df = n-1)
Var.
Representation.Detail: Variance based on a sample; calculated with n-1 (n = sample size) degrees of freedom. This is the "normal" variance used in almost all cases. A variance is a standard deviation squared.
Representation.Label: Varianz (Stichprobe, Freiheitsgrade = n-1)
Var.
Representation.Detail: Streuung der Werte in einer Stichprobe, berechnet mit n-1 Freiheitsgraden (n = Stichprobenumfang). Dies ist die "normale" Varianz die in fast allen Fällen verwendet wird.

ues:Specification.debuglabel: ### This and the following are variance measures. Note that most are dimensionless with the exception of the interquartile range. NOTE: Although not entirely true (the dimension of the variance is the square of the measurement unit), for practical purposes it may be treated as dimensionless.

Representation.Label: Variance (population; df = n; rarely applicable!)
Var. (pop.)
Representation.Detail: Variance of population, calculated with n (= sample size) degrees of freedom. Use this if the entire population of objects has been studied. Normally conclusions about the population are based on a sample that has been studied; in this case the "normal" variance with df = n-1 is appropriate.
Representation.Label: Varianz (Grundgesamtheit, n Freiheitsgrade)
Var./G
Representation.Detail: Varianz einer Grundgesamtheit, berechnet mit n (= Stichprobenumfang) Freiheitsgraden. In den meisten Fällen macht man Rückschlüsse auf die Grundgesamtheit anhand einer Stichprobe; in diesem Fall ist die "normale" Standardabweichung mit n-1 Freiheitsgraden zu verwenden.

Representation.Label: Standard deviation (sample)
s.d.
Representation.Detail: Standard deviation based on a sample, calculated with n-1 (n = sample size) degrees of freedom. This is the "normal" standard deviation used in almost all cases.
Representation.Label: Standardabweichung (Stichprobe, Freiheitsgrade = n-1)
Std.Abw.
Representation.Detail: Standardabweichung einer Stichprobe, berechnet mit n-1 Freiheitsgraden (n = Stichprobenumfang). Dies ist die "normale" Standardabweichung die in fast allen Fällen verwendet wird.

Representation.Label: Standard deviation (population; df = n; rarely applicable!)
s.d. (pop.)
Representation.Detail: Standard deviation based on the entire population; calculated with n (= sample size) degrees of freedom. Use this if the entire population of objects has been studied. Normally conclusions about the population are based on a sample that has been studied; in this case the "normal" std. dev. with df = n-1 is appropriate.
Representation.Label: Standardabweichung (Grundgesamtheit; n Freiheitsgrade)
Std.Abw./G
Representation.Detail: Standardabweichung einer Grundgesamtheit; berechnet mit n (= Stichprobenumfang) Freiheitsgraden. In den meisten Fällen macht man Rückschlüsse auf die Grundgesamtheit anhand einer Stichprobe; in diesem Fall ist die "normale" Standardabweichung mit n-1 Freiheitsgraden zu verwenden.

Representation.Label: Mean deviation
m.d.
Representation.Detail: The mean of the absolute differences from the arithmetic mean of values. The absolute differences are the positive, unsquared differences from the mean.
Representation.Label: Mittlere Abweichung.
Mittl.Abw.
Mean deviation from median
m.d.m.
Representation.Detail: The mean of the absolute differences from the median of values. The absolute differences are the positive, unsquared differences from the mode.
Representation.Label: Mittlere Abweichung vom Median.
Mittl.Abw.
Coefficient of variation (sample)
CV
Representation.Detail: Standard deviation (based on a sample), divided by the mean. The values entered should not be expressed as percent, but converted to a true value (use '0.3' for 30%). According to Sokal & Rohlf 1981:59 this is a biased estimate, which may be corrected, compare 'CVC'.
Representation.Label: Varianzkoeffizient (Stichprobe, Freiheitsgrade = n-1)
VK
Representation.Detail: Standardabweichung einer Stichprobe (n-1 Freiheitsgrade) geteilt durch den Mittelwert.

Representation.Label: Corrected coefficient of variation (sample)
CVC
Representation.Detail: Corrected coefficient corrected by (1 + (1/4n)). Compare, e. g., Sokal & Rohlf 1981:59'.
Representation.Label: Korrigierter Varianzkoeffizient (Stichprobe, Freiheitsgrade = n-1)
VK
Representation.Detail: Varianzkoeffizient korrigiert mit (1 + (1/4n)). Vergleiche Sokal & Rohlf 1981:59'.

Representation.Label: Total range
TR
Representation.Detail: The maximum value minus the minimum value. Also often called "Range" without further qualification like 'absolute', 'total'. This measure can normally be computed automatically based on minimum and maximum. It will be manually entered, if minimum and maximum are not separately cited in a publication.
Representation.Label: Gesamtdifferenz
TR
Representation.Detail: Maximum minus Minimum.

Representation.Label: Interquartile range
IQR
Representation.Detail: This is the length of a symmetric interval around median, containing 50% of observations.
Representation.Label: Quartilsdifferenz
QD
Representation.Detail: Dies ist die Länge eines symmetrischen Intervalls um den Median welches 50% der Beobachtungen enthält.

Representation.Label: Standard error of mean
s.e.
Representation.Detail: The standard error of mean is defined as: "std. dev. / square root(n)" (with n = sample size)
Representation.Label: Standardfehler (Mittelwert)
SF
Standard error of variance (of multiple samples)
s.e.(var.)
Representation.Detail: This is not a variance measure of the mean, but a measure of the variance of the variance estimates.
Representation.Label: Standardfehler der Varianz (bei multiple samples)
SF (var.)
Representation.Detail: Der Standardfehler der Varianz kann nur bei mehreren Stichproben bestimmt werden. Dies ist kein Streuungsmaß für den Mittelwert, sondern ein Maß für die Streuung der Varianzschätzungen!

ues:Specification.debuglabel: (ReportingClass = Other because not variance measure of mean!)

Representation.Label: Skewness
Skw.
Representation.Detail: Coefficient of skewness of a distribution, a measure of the degree of asymmetry of a distribution around its mean: <0 if mode < median, =0 if symmetric, > 0 if mode > median.
Representation.Label: Schiefe
Sch.
Representation.Detail: Schiefe der Verteilung: <0 wenn Modus < Median, =0 wenn symmetrisch, > 0 wenn Modus > Median.

ues:Specification.debuglabel: ### This and the following are other distribution measures (other than range, central, variance):

Representation.Label: Kurtosis
Kurt.
Representation.Detail: Coefficient of kurtosis of distribution, a measure of the "peakedness" of a distribution. A normal distribution has a value of 0.263, larger values indicate wider, smaller narrower distributions.
Representation.Label: Kurtosis
Kurt.
Representation.Detail: Exzess (Kurtosis) der Verteilung. Eine Normalverteilung hat einen Wert von 0,263, größere Werte zeigen zu breite, kleinere Werte zu schmale Verteilungen an.

Representation.Label: Stichprobenumfang
n
Representation.Detail: Die Anzahl der Beobachtungen auf denen die angegebenen statistischen Maße (Mittelwert, Standardabweichung, etc.) beruhen.
Representation.Label: Sample size
n
Representation.Detail: The number of objects studied and on which the other reported statistical measures (mean, standard deviation, etc.) are based.

ues:Specification.debuglabel: ### Sample size is in a class of its own!

Representation.Label: Lower limit of {ParameterValue}% confidence interval for mean.
-CI{ParameterValue}
Representation.Detail: The confidence interval is defined as a range into which the true mean of the distribution falls with a certain probability. The parameter expresses the confidence level in percent. Typical values are: 99.9% (= 0.05% from left!), 99% (= 0.5% from left), 95% (= 2.5% from left), 90% (= 5% from left).
Representation.Label: Untere Grenze des {ParameterValue}%-Konfidenzintervalls für den Mittelwert
-CI{ParameterValue}

ues:Specification.debuglabel: This and the following are statistical range measures:

Representation.Label: Upper limit of {ParameterValue}% confidence interval for mean.
+CI{ParameterValue}
Representation.Detail: The confidence interval is defined as a range into which the true mean of the distribution falls with a certain probability. The probability is expressed in percent in a parameter called; typical values are: 99.9 (= 99.95% from left!), 99 (= 99.5% from left), 95 (= 97.5% from left), 90 (= 95% from left).
Representation.Label: Obere Grenze des {ParameterValue}%-Konfidenzintervalls für den Mittelwert
+CI{ParameterValue}
{ParameterValue}% percentile
-P{ParameterValue}
Representation.Detail: The {ParameterValue}% percentile is defined such that {ParameterValue}% of the observations are smaller than this value. Typical parameter values are 2.5, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25 (= 1st quartile), 30. Do not use 50; use the 'Median' measure instead!
Representation.Label: {ParameterValue}% Quantil
-P{ParameterValue}
Representation.Detail: Das {ParameterValue}%Quantil ist der Wert der größer oder gleich {ParameterValue}% der Beobachtungen ist.

Representation.Label: {ParameterValue}% percentile
+P{ParameterValue}
Representation.Detail: The {ParameterValue}% percentile is defined such that {ParameterValue}% of the observations are smaller than this value. Typical parameter values are 70, 75 (= 3rd quartile), 80, 90, 95, 97.5. Do not use 50; use the 'Median' measure instead!
Representation.Label: {ParameterValue}% Quantil
+P{ParameterValue}
Representation.Detail: Das {ParameterValue}%Quantil ist der Wert der größer oder gleich {ParameterValue}% der Beobachtungen ist.

Representation.Label: {ParameterValue}% trim mean
+TM{ParameterValue}
Representation.Detail: The arithmetic mean of the symmetric {ParameterValue}% interior portion of a set of data values.

Representation.Label: Mean minus {ParameterValue} stand. deviation(s)
µ - {ParameterValue} s.d.
Representation.Detail: Lower limit of a range calculated as mean minus standard deviations. The parameter ParameterValue (here {ParameterValue}) defines a factor with which the s.d. is multiplied before it is substracted from the mean. Typical parameter values are 1 or 2.
Representation.Label: Mittelwert minus {ParameterValue} Standardabweichung(en).
µ - {ParameterValue} Std.abw.
Mean plus {ParameterValue} stand. deviation(s)
µ + {ParameterValue} s.d.
Representation.Detail: Upper limit of a range calculated as mean plus standard deviations. The parameter ParameterValue (here {ParameterValue}) defines a factor with which the s.d. is multiplied before it is added to the mean. Typical parameter values are 1 or 2.
Representation.Label: Mittelwert plus {ParameterValue} Standardabweichung(en).
µ + {ParameterValue} Std.abw.
Minimum; outlier corrected ({ParameterValue} std. dev.)
Min\{ParameterValue} s.d.
Representation.Detail: Absolute minimum value of sample, excluding outlier values more than {ParameterValue} standard deviations distant from the mean. Typical parameter values are 3 or 4.
Representation.Label: Minimum; Outlier-korrigiert ({ParameterValue} std. dev.).
Min\{ParameterValue} Std.abw.
Maximum; outlier corrected ({ParameterValue} std. dev.)
Max\{ParameterValue} s.d.
Representation.Detail: Absolute maximum value of sample, excluding outlier values more than {ParameterValue} standard deviations distant from the mean. Typical parameter values are 3 or 4.
Representation.Label: Maximum; Outlier-korrigiert ({ParameterValue} std. dev.).
Max\{ParameterValue} Std.abw.
UnivarSimpleStatMeasure
Representation.Detail: An enumeration of univariate statistical measures supported by UBIF (esp. used by SDD). Compare also UnivarParamStatMeasureEnum, containing further statistical measures that use an additional parameter (for percentage of percentile or confidence interval, etc.).

Representation.Label: AgentRole
Representation.Detail: Provides codes for roles like author, editor, photographer, advisor, or copyright holder. The roles and their codes used here are based on http://www.loc.gov/marc.relators/ (as of 2004/6 available at http://dublincore.org/usage/meetings/2004/03/Relator-codes.html). For example, the enumerated code "aut" for author corresponds to http://www.loc.gov/marc.relators/aut. The DublinCore Agents group is considering using the same codes (see e. g. http://www.loc.gov/marc/dc/Agent-roles.html), but as of 2004/6 the DublinCore Agents subgroup did not yet agree on a Creator/Contributor refinement as qualified DublinCore. Note that the roles selected here are a subset of the roles that are available in MARC. See second annotation for reasons of not using a union-design, which would be easier to maintain!
Representation.Label: AgentRole
Representation.Detail: Technical note: It would be preferable to define the values in separate enumerations and define this as xs:union memberTypes="AgentCreatorRoleEnum AgentContributorRoleEnum AgentOwnerRoleEnum". However, whereas XML Spy accepts this, Stylus Studio and Xerces have problems in accepting that a member type of a union may be a restriction of the union type including this member. Furthermore, Xerces has problems in understanding that a union of two types, each of which is a restrictions of QName, may be a restriction of QName. Therefore, as of 2005-03, a long enumeration is defined here which is then restricted to shorter enumerations. - Gregor Hagedorn

Representation.Label: Author
Representation.Detail: A person or corporate body chiefly responsible for the intellectual or artistic content of a work. This term may also be used when more than one person or body bears such responsibility.

Representation.Label: Editor
Representation.Detail: A person who prepares for publication a work not primarily his/her own, such as by elucidating text, adding introductory or other critical matter, or technically directing an editorial staff.

Representation.Label: Creator in general
Representation.Detail: A person or corporate body responsible for the intellectual or artistic content of a work. The more specific type Author [aut] or Editor [edt] should be preferred.

Representation.Label: Illustrator
Representation.Detail: The person who conceives, and perhaps also implements, a design or illustration, usually to accompany a written text.

Representation.Label: Photographer
Representation.Detail: The person or organization responsible for taking photographs, whether they are used in their original form or as reproductions.

Representation.Label: Contributor in general
Representation.Detail: Someone whose work has been contributed to a larger work, such as an anthology, serial publication, or other compilation of individual works. Do not use for someone whose sole function in relation to a work is as author, editor, compiler or translator.

Representation.Label: Translator
Representation.Detail: A person who renders a text from one language into another, from an older form of a language into the modern form, or from one audience-specific representation to one appropriate for another audience.

Representation.Label: Transcriber
Representation.Detail: A person who prepares a handwritten or typewritten copy from original material, including from dictated or orally recorded material.

Representation.Label: Collaborator
Representation.Detail: A person or corporate body that takes a limited part in the elaboration of a work of another person or corporate body that brings complements (e.g., appendices, notes) to the work.

Representation.Label: Collector
Representation.Detail: A person who has brought together material from various sources, which has been arranged, described, and catalogued as a collection. The collector is neither the creator of the material nor the person to whom manuscripts in the collection may have been addressed.

Representation.Label: Correspondent
Representation.Detail: A person or organization who was either the writer or recipient of a letter or other communication.

Representation.Label: Programmer
Representation.Detail: A person or corporate body responsible for the creation and/or maintenance of computer program design documents, source code, and machine-executable digital files and supporting documentation.

Representation.Label: Research team head
Representation.Detail: The person or corporate body that directed or managed a research project.

Representation.Label: Research team member
Representation.Detail: The person or corporate body that participated in a research project but whose role did not involve direction or management of it.

Representation.Label: Researcher
Representation.Detail: The person or corporate body responsible for performing research.

Representation.Label: Scientific advisor
Representation.Detail: A person who brings scientific, pedagogical, or historical competence to the conception and realization on a work, particularly in the case of audio-visual items.

Representation.Label: Proofreader
Representation.Detail: A person who corrects text (orthography, grammar).

Representation.Label: Markup editor
Representation.Detail: The person or organization performing the coding of SGML, HTML, or XML markup of metadata, text, etc.

Representation.Label: Commentator
Representation.Detail: A person who provides interpretation, analysis, or a discussion of the subject matter on a recording, motion picture, or other audiovisual medium.

Representation.Label: Reviewer
Representation.Detail: A person or corporate body responsible for the review of book, motion picture, performance, etc.

Representation.Label: Consultant
Representation.Detail: The person called upon for professional advice or services in a specialized field of knowledge or training.

Representation.Label: Owner
Representation.Detail: The person or organization that currently owns an item or collection.

Representation.Label: Former owner
Representation.Detail: The person or organization who owned an item at any time in the past. Includes those to whom the material was once presented. The person or organization giving the item to the present owner is designated as Donor [dnr]

Representation.Label: Copyright holder
Representation.Detail: A person or organization owning the copyright of the material.

Representation.Label: Copyright claimant
Representation.Detail: The person listed as a copyright owner at the time of registration. Copyright can be granted or later transferred to another person or agent, at which time the claimant becomes the copyright holder.

Representation.Label: Donor
Representation.Detail: The donor of a book, manuscript, etc., to its present owner. Donors to previous owners are designated as Former owner [fmo]

Representation.Label: Depositor
Representation.Detail: A person or organization placing material in the physical custody of a library or repository without transferring the legal title.

Representation.Label: AgentCreatorContribRole
Representation.Detail: Union of AgentCreatorRoleEnum and AgentContributorRoleEnum, but no Owner roles. Technical note: currently this is modeled somewhat strangely as an xml-schema restriction of AgentRoleEnum (= union of all three basic role groups). This is a workaround for a problem Xerxes 2.6.2 detected by Jacob Asiedu! We hope that in the future the whole 'xs:restriction' below can be replaced again with the much more straightforward 'xs:union memberTypes="AgentCreatorRoleEnum AgentContributorRoleEnum"/' (= union of the two intended AgentRole enumerations).
